sub_title: Business Developer | Hydrogen & Renewable Energy sectors | Complex Problem Solver | Team Player & Inclusive Leader

projects.title: FlexiFuel-SOFC
projects.description:
Micro-scale CHP systems are presently mainly based on fossil fuels. Examples therefore are natural gas and heating oil fired applications based on block heating works, Stirling engines and steam expansion machines. Attempts to couple these technologies with biomass combustion processes have so far not led to marketable products. Moreover, the electric efficiencies of such applications would be rather low (typically 8 to 14% related to the biomass input power).

An alternative option to combustion based CHP technologies are gasification based micro-scale CHP technologies. Such systems have already been introduced into the market. They are usually based on downdraft or multi-stage gasification systems coupled with gas cleaning systems and gas engines. They exhibit higher electric efficiencies (~ 25%) but limited overall efficiencies (65-75%) due to intermediate gas cooling steps. Other disadvantages are the high fuel quality requirements (usually only high-quality wood chips with low moisture contents and well defined particle sizes can be utilised), high efforts for gas cleaning as well as rather complex process schemes.

To overcome these problems and to develop a highly efficient and fuel-flexible micro-scale biomass CHP technology a new approach has been chosen within this project.

projects.title: KnowHY
projects.description: KnowHy is a 3 years European FP7-project (funded by the European Commission and coordinated by the Fuel Cell and Hydrogen Joint Undertaking) that aims at providing to the widest possible audience of technicians specific training modules, practical, in an appropriate format and at affordable cost, to facilitate the deployment of the FC&H2 technologies expected to enter the market within the time frame 2014-2020.

projects.title: Reinvent the Toilet Challenge
projects.description:
Since 2011 TU Delft has been a participant in the Reinvent the Toilet Challenge funded by the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation. We propose a community-based sanitation system that processes water on-site and upgrades urine and feces to energy at an omni-gasification plant. Human waste is dried, converted to syngas and fed into a fuel cell. The gasification process instantly destroys pathogens and generates enough energy to power the system, creating a sustainable cycle.
Other focal areas in our project are the design of a water diverting toilet and a Community Sanitation Centre, as well as the recognition of women empowerment, branding and sustainable business modeling.

contributors.headline: Business Developer | Hydrogen & Renewable Energy sectors | Complex Problem Solver | Team Player & Inclusive Leader

projects.title: System Integration Project
projects.description: In the course System Integration Project, part of the MSc Sustainable Energy Technology, I had the chance to model and analyse integrated energy systems. In this course, I analysed resources geographic availability and the energy consumption profiles of a 100-dwellings neighbourhood, identified available subsidies, and performed a simplified environmental and economic assessment with a sensitivity analysis on the CO2 market price.

projects.title: Design, Installation and Commisioning of an OSEC plant in a rural community in Guatemala
projects.description:
The objective of the project is the installation of a machine for the production of a disinfectant
solution of sodium hypochlorite in a Guatemalan agricultural cooperative. The machine used is an
On-Site Electrolytic Chlorinator (OSEC) converting a mixture of water and table salt into sodium
hypochlorite. This is obtained by electrolysis. The solution can be used to purify water that can
then be used for drinking, farming and cleaning; chlorine kills bacteria and viruses and makes
water safe for drinking. In addition, the device will be fitted with two probes, one for electricity
consumption and one for flow rate, to enable constant monitoring; the probes will be connected
to the GSM network in order to enable long distance monitoring.
The community currently purchases the disinfectant from external suppliers. Through this project
the cooperative will be able to cost-effectively produce the disinfectant autonomously, at a lower
cost than the purchase price and eco-friendly. In October 2011 an on-the-spot investigation was
performed, during which the daily consumption of chlorine of the cooperative was monitored. It
was then possible to determine the annual amount of sodium hypochlorite solution required and
the saving obtained by installing the chlorinator system.
It was then decided that the cooperative will pay back 25% of the chlorinator cost in a two years
period  time.  After  this  period,  it  was  agreed  that  any  further  savings  will  be  used  to  finance
educational  projects  in  the  community  itself.  The  project  was  accomplished  thanks  to  the
cooperation between CIRPS, Amka Onlus and the cooperative of Nuevo Horizonte.
